Kerman is a city located 15 miles outside of Fresno in California’s rural San Joaquin Valley, which is a major agricultural area. Kerman Unified opened a school-based health center (SBHC) in 2013 to serve all students at the eight schools in the district. It is operated by Valley Health Team, a local Federally Qualified Health…
webpage_tree.excerpt: School-based health centers (SBHCs) in California, often operated by federally qualified health centers and community partners, are addressing public health challenges by distributing naloxone, engaging youth in tobacco prevention, promoting healthy eating, and improving access to nutritious foods through innovative programs. These SBHCs collaborate with students, families, and community members to enhance student health, well-being, and school attendance, particularly in underserved urban and rural areas. Their efforts include peer-led education, campus wellness initiatives, and policy advocacy to create healthier school environments.

webpage_tree.title: Our Work
webpage_tree.content:
Who We Are

The California School-Based Health Alliance (CSHA) is the statewide nonprofit organization helping to put more health services in schools. CSHA supports local education agencies and community organizations in launching, enhancing, and sustaining school health services. We influence state laws and  policies by advocating to improve access by making school-based health and wellness centers are an integral part of the health care and education systems. Healthier children are better able to attend and focus in class. Our conference , webinars , resources, and technical assistance help school-based health centers and wellness centers offer high quality, age-appropriate care to kids by putting health care where kids are—at school. Join one of our regional coalitions in the Central Valley , Northern California , and Inland Empire . Contact us if you are working in a school health program in California and want to be connected.

SUPPORTING SCHOOL BASED HEALTH CENTERS

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE &TRAININGS

POLICY & ADVOCACY IN CALIFORNIA

RESOURCES & GUIDANCE

Explore Our Resources

See our in-depth guides on starting, expanding and improving sustainable health services for kids in schools.

School-Based Health & Wellness Centers In California

School-based health and wellness centers are located in schools serving some of the state’s most vulnerable children. On campuses with SBHCs, about 70% of students receive free or reduced price meals. Students in communities that benefit from school-based health and wellness centers are less likely to have health insurance or access to health and mental health services that address these risk factors. Without access to high-quality health services, childhood risk factors are more likely to be translated into higher rates of diabetes, heart disease, cancer, and other chronic illnesses in adulthood as well as more struggles with academic success. Of California’s 400 school-based health and wellness centers: Most of California’s SBHCs are physically located right on campus within a main building or in a portable. In some areas, health services are provided by mobile medical or dental vans, and in other areas, “school-linked” health centers are off campus and have formal operating agreements with schools. School-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHCs/WCs) are spread from Del Norte to San Diego County with large concentrations in Los Angeles and the San Francisco Bay Area. When looking at our map, note: Would you like to be added? Complete our survey to help us have a more complete list of school-based health and wellness centers.

Explore Our Resources

A comprehensive resource for anyone seeking to start or expand health services at school. The Best Practices Checklist is designed to help school-based health and wellness center staff identify areas where they can strengthen their practices and improve the quality and sustainability of services. See the high-level activities you can do now to start health services at school. Swipe to see more

Stay Up to Date on School-based Health Centers

Sign up to receive our free newsletter and advocate for kids’ health. Organizations that want to receive technical assistance, discounted conference registration, and access to regular member calls can become a member.

children.title: 2025 School Health Conference
children.content:
The Power of Partnerships

Our 2025 School Health Conference was held April 28-29, 2025, at the Hyatt Regency Orange County near Anaheim.

Experience Our Conference

Moments From Our 2025 Conference

Photography by Vita Vivet Film Productions .

2025 Keynote Speaker

Saun-Toy Trotter , LMFT, is a healer and psychotherapist with over 20 years of experience providing trauma-informed and culturally responsive behavioral health care to adolescents and families. She has experience in school health centers, residential treatment facilities, in-patient, and psychiatric units, and her practice is rooted in youth development principles. At UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital Oakland, she has expanded school-based services to include health education and youth advisory boards. Saun-Toy is a contributing author to School Social Work: Engaging Social Justice and Racial Equity from a Practitioners Perspective . She loves working in schools and is committed to evidence-based and culturally rooted practices that foster individual and collective health, wellbeing, and liberation. Loading…

How to Find Session Materials

Are you looking for workshop handouts and presentation slides? Log in to Whova where you can find presentation materials – if shared by the presenter – listed below the description for each session.

Thank You to Our 2025 Sponsors!

CalOptima Health is the single largest health insurer in Orange County administering Medi-Cal for nearly 1 million Orange County residents. Our mission is to serve member health with excellence and dignity, respecting the value and needs of each person. Blue Shield of California strives to create a healthcare system worthy of our family and friends that is sustainably affordable. Blue Shield of California is a tax paying, nonprofit, independent member of the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association with 8 million members, 7,200 employees and more than $24 billion in annual revenue. Founded in 1939 in San Francisco and now headquartered in Oakland, Blue Shield of California and its affiliates provide health, dental, vision, Medicaid and Medicare healthcare service plans in California. The company has contributed more than $643 million to Blue Shield of California Foundation since 2002 to have an impact on California communities. Anthem is dedicated to delivering better care to our members, providing greater value to our customers and helping improve the health of our communities. Schools are passionate about ensuring that all students succeed, but they can’t address the health of their employees and students alone. That’s why Kaiser Permanente created Thriving Schools . We’re committed to serving as a valuable partner in health to schools and districts across the country, helping to ensure that teachers, staff, and students have the support they need to thrive — in learning and in health. Eager minds, healthy bodies, and quality care: The Los Angeles Trust for Children’s Health is bringing health and education together to end healthcare inequities and achieve student wellness for all. ACEs Aware is a first-in-the nation effort to promote early detection and intervention to mitigate the health and societal impacts of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) and toxic stress. We offer free training, screening tools, clinical protocols, and payment for ACE screening. ACEs Aware strives to create a better world for our children, families, and communities by working together across sectors to prevent and address the impact of ACEs and toxic stress.

children.title: Northern School Health Coalition
children.content:
Next Meeting: Fall 2025

Join the California School-Based Health Alliance for our Northern School Health Coalition meeting that aims to bring together school-based health partners from across the region! This group is for Northern California educators and health, mental health, and other student support practitioners. Please reach out to Sierra Lau with any questions. Location: Virtual Time: TBD, Fall 2025 This group is for educators and health, mental health, and other student support practitioners from counties in far northern California:

Are you a member of the California School-Based Health Alliance?

Organizations that join as members receive valuable benefits – including discounted registration to our California School Health Conference – and a limited number of complimentary hours of technical assistance.

About the Northern School Health Coalition

There is growing recognition in the role health and well-being plays in the success of students. School-based health centers (SBHCs), defined as health clinics located on or near school campuses where children and youth can get immediate help for acute and chronic conditions as well as preventative care, are positioned to help create more equitable access to care for youth. The California School-Based Health Alliance’s Student Health Index — designed to identify opportunities to expand health care in schools — revealed that Lake and Tehama Counties are among the top 10 counties with the highest ratio of high need schools to all schools.

Purpose

The purpose of the Northern School Health Coalition is to expand and support the SBHC movement, and to facilitate greater engagement, investment, and proliferation of school health services, all of which equate to greater access for youth.

children.title: Inland Empire
children.content:
Save the Date: 2025 Inland Empire School Health Symposium

Join the California School-Based Health Alliance on Monday, October 6, 2025, from 8:00 am-3:00 pm for our 2nd Annual Inland Empire School Health Symposium meeting that brings together school-based health partners across Riverside and San Bernardino Counties! This event is for Inland Empire educators and health, mental health, and other student support practitioners. Location & Registration Details: TBD

Are you a member of the California School-Based Health Alliance?

Organizations that join as members receive valuable benefits – including discounted registration to our California School Health Conference – and a limited number of complimentary hours of technical assistance. Monday, October 6, 2025 9:00 am – 3:00 pm San Bernardino County 11:00 am – 2:00 pm 11:00 am – 2:00 pm April 27-28, 2026 Los Angeles County 11:00 am – 2:00 pm San Bernardino, CA

About the Inland Empire School Health Coalition

There is growing recognition in the role health and well-being plays in the success of students. School-based health centers (SBHCs), defined as health clinics located on or near school campuses where children and youth can get immediate help for acute and chronic conditions as well as preventative care, are positioned to help create more equitable access to care for youth. Interest and momentum are building among local stakeholders in the Inland Empire region of California (Riverside and San Bernardino Counties) to develop new school-based health and wellness centers. The California School-Based Health Alliance’s Student Health Index — designed to identify opportunities to expand health care in schools — revealed that San Bernardino County has five of the top ten school districts with the highest ratio of high need schools to total schools.
Purpose
The purpose of the Inland Empire School-Based Health Centers Coalition (coalition) is to expand and support the SBHC movement, and to facilitate greater engagement, investment, and proliferation of school health services, all of which equate to greater access for youth.
Goals

Develop Partnerships

Leverage Support

Technical Assistance

Steering Committee

The development and maintenance of the coalition is supported by the California School-Based Health Alliance. We do this in partnership with representatives from partner health, education, and community based agencies from throughout the region. The steering committee provides leadership and guidance around the development and operations of the coalition, which includes planning convenings and serving as a channel of communication about school-based health care.
School-Based Health Center Webinar Series
The California School-Based Health Alliance has partnered with the San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schools to present a series of webinars on bringing school-based health and wellness centers to schools.
The School Health Connection Podcast
The School Health Connection Podcast is your go-to source for insights and inspiration in creating healthier school environments. Brought to you by the California School-Based Health Alliance, Inland Empire School Health Coalition, and in collaboration with the San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schools.
Resources from Our 2024 Fall Inland Empire School-Based Health Symposium
Symposium Keynote Speaker
Yesenia Ceballos , M.A., APCC, PPS, has dedicated over two decades to the field of education, with extensive experience as both a teacher and school counselor in diverse school settings. She currently serves as the Wellness Counselor at Sierra High School (SHS) in San Bernardino, where her leadership has played a key role in the school being named one of America’s Healthiest Schools for two consecutive years and a member of the Recognized ASCA Model Program (RAMP) team. Driven by her personal journey, Yesenia is passionate about advocating for historically underserved youth, working as a catalyst for change. She partners with community-based organizations to provide students with access to evidence-based therapies and physical health services and has established a resource center that is open to the entire community.

Developing & Implementing Universal Screening Efforts at a Wellness Center

Schools are a critical provider of services to address the socio-emotional, behavioral health, and basic needs of students. Universal screening offers one avenue for systematically evaluating, identifying, and monitoring the needs of an entire student population. Acknowledging the reality of limited school-based resources for supporting ongoing screening efforts, this workshop will review the development and beta implementation of a novel digital system that enables identification of at-risk students via the administration of brief, psychometrically valid measures; expedited identification and referral to relevant services via automatic scoring and filtering; as well as ongoing progress tracking at individual and school-wide levels. Presenter: Shayna Greenberg , MA, PhD Student, Loma Linda University

What Drives Student Health: Integrating Social Drivers of Health & Equity

This workshop explores the impact of social drivers of health (SDOH) on student well-being and academic achievement, framed within the Whole Child, Whole School, Whole Community (WSCC) model. Participants will gain insights into how SDOH affects student well-being and academic success. The session will highlight the importance of integrating equity and justice into these discussions, emphasizing the establishment of student health centers as a key strategy. Presenter: Brianna Vasquez , MPH, CHES, Health Education Specialist II, San Bernardino County Department of Public Health

Riverside County Office of Education’s CAREspace

RCOE CAREspace provides free mental health and related services to students, families, staff, schools, and the community of Riverside County. In collaboration with our 9 community partners, we have 11 CAREspace locations (wellness centers) where we provide in person and telehealth services. In this workshop you will learn about CAREspace services, our referral process, data collection and outcomes, and be able to ask questions around developing or expanding your wellness center or school-based health center. Looking forward to connecting with you! Presenter: Lexi Backstrom , EdD, EdS, MA, MBA, PPS, LMFT, LPCC, Administrator, Behavioral Health, Riverside County Office of Education

California Children & Youth Behavioral Health Initiative (CYBHI) – Reimaging Our Ecosystem and Supports for Children

Academic issues, poor attendance, behavior issues, health concerns, and poor social relations are a few of the adverse impacts for children experiencing mental health needs that go untreated. This has been a growing concern across California, leading to adverse child outcomes. To help address these needs, California Health and Human Services has made an unprecedented $4.7 billion investment to reimagine integrated ecosystems called the Children and Youth Behavioral Health Initiative (CYBHI). In this presentation, you will hear how the CYBHI workstreams are supporting opportunities to improve outcomes for children. Presenter: Michael Lombardo , MA, Public Administration and Policy Advisor for Human Services and Education Agencies, MCL Collaboration

Creative Financing & Sustainability of School-Based Wellness Centers

This workshop will provide a model for integrated behavioral health services operated through middle or high school Wellness Centers.  Participants will walk away with a Wellness Center guide providing a clear system for accessing services which are reimbursable and integrated within the school.  Services include Coordination of Services Team Meetings, peer services, mentoring, outreach, case management, behavioral health direct services, group services, and other means of correction. Presenter: Jose Campos , MEd, MEd Admin, Director, Jurupa Unified School District

IEHP Healthy School Program

In collaboration with Local Education Agencies (LEAs), aligning with the statewide initiative – the Student Behavioral Health Incentive Program (SBHIP) and IEHP’s Health Navigator (HN) Program – we seek to provide targeted services and supports to identified students and their families. The Program empowers IEHP Members to easily access preventive services and receive care for their chronic conditions (i.e., Asthma, etc.). The Program promotes appropriate utilization of health care services such as: the afterhours Nurse Advice Line Urgent Care Clinics, and Primary Care Providers to ensure Members receive the care they need when they need it and at the right place and at the right time. This promotion of appropriate health care utilization will ensure students are in school ready to learn! The HN will also make sure to connect students and their families to community and Health Plan resources based on need. As a program, we intend to form strong partnerships with school staff (counselors, health aides, Principals, teachers, office personnel, etc.) to help support the students/families in need in areas of physical, mental, and social wellbeing. Presenter: Sonia Rivas , Health Navigator Program Manager, Inland Empire Health Plan

Transforming Our Partnerships for Student Success: Addressing Behavioral Health and Non-Academic Needs in an Upstream and Universal Manner

This workshop will share the successes and learnings from a 4-year partnership between Riverside University Health System and Hemet Unified School District. Through a system of tiered behavioral health services, universal holistic health screening, and onsite and community-based support, students and families have behavioral health and non-academic needs met. 7,000+ unique students across 7 schools have been screened through the program, and over 4,500 behavioral health services and 93,000 units of social services have been delivered. Of note, the percentage of students with concerning behavioral health needs has decreased from a baseline of 15% in 2020 to 7% in 2023. Presenters: Geoffrey Leung , Public Health Officer, Riverside University Health System and Riverside County; Janine Moore , Deputy Director for Children’s and Transitional Age Youth Programs, Riverside University Health System Behavioral Health

A Bold New Approach to School-Based Services Financing: A Deep Dive into the CYBHI Fee Schedule

In this session, the Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) will demystify and share lessons learned from the first cohort of the CYBHI Fee Schedule program. Participants will learn about DHCS’ progress in implementing the CYBHI Fee Schedule program, including frequently asked questions, and will have the opportunity to ask burning questions. Presenter: Autumn Boylan , MPH, Deputy Director at the California Department of Health Care Services

They Came, So We Built It

Session description: This workshop offers an inside look at the development of Sierra High School’s School-Based Health Center through the perspectives of Principal Hector Murrieta and Wellness Teacher Ian Niewoehner. In public schools, we don’t build it and wait for them to come; they come to us, and we build it. Participants will learn how Sierra HS established a SBHC now in its 5th year. Hector will discuss the vision, partnerships, personnel, and funding needed. Ian will share insights on developing and teaching the Wellness class, a vital component of the center’s success. Presenters: Hector Murrieta , MA, Principal, Sierra High School; Ian Niewoehner , MA, Teacher, Sierra High School

Partnering With an FQHC to Bring School-Based Health

Explore the model of partnering with a Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC) to provide school-based health services. We will walk through the steps from idea to implementation and finally how the operations of a SBHC look when operated by an FQHC. Attendees will learn about federal and state requirements, funding methods, honest expectations and learned lessons. Presenter: Angel Acevedo , MBA, Director of Policy & Special Projects, Community Health Systems, Inc.

Centering Youth Voice Through Advocacy + Engagement in School-Based Health

This workshop will explore strategies for amplifying youth voices and empowering students to take an active role in shaping school-based health initiatives. Through engagement and advocacy, participants will learn how to create inclusive environments that prioritize the needs and perspectives of young people in decision-making. Presenter: Marina Quintanilla , MPH, CHES, Youth Advocacy and Engagement Manager, California School-based Health Alliance

Building Data Sharing Partnerships to Support Student Attendance

Session description: This workshop will dive into data sharing between a community academic partnership (Loma Linda University Health and El Sol Neighborhood Educational Center) and two local school districts in San Bernardino County. Participants will learn about data share agreements and how 1) What data is needed to meet goals and objectives of contracts, 2) how data systems set-up 3) how data is collected, and 4) how data is shared and analyzed to drive program improvement and outcomes. Presenter: Cristie Granillo , MS, Med, Manager-Community Health Worker Integration, Loma Linda University Health

Healthy Mouths, Strong Minds: Boosting Student Achievement Through Oral Health Partnerships

Poor oral health can hinder students’ academic performance due to missed school days, concentration issues, and lower self-esteem, that ultimately impact classroom achievement and school funding. This workshop will discuss the current state of children’s oral health in the Inland Empire and existing school initiatives to improve oral health. Participants will explore on-campus oral health programs and learn how districts can collaborate with dental professionals and navigators to provide care and referral services. By the end, participants will be equipped with practical tools to advocate for and implement effective oral health programs that enhance student health and academic success. Presenter: Bonnie Flippin , MBA, Program Coordinator, San Bernardino County Department of Public Health – Smile SBC

Cal-AIM – Community Supports

Community Supports are services provided by Medi-Cal managed care plans (MCPs) to address Medi-Cal members’ health-related social needs, help them live healthier lives, and avoid higher, costlier levels of care. At Inland Empire Health Plan, we offer all 14 Community Supports (examples: housing transition, housing deposits, housing tenancy, respite services, etc.) This workshop will provide an overview of California’s CalAim Community Support initiative and how your students/family can be referred for Community Supports. Presenter: Carmen Vega , MSLM, CHW, Director, Community Supports, Inland Empire Health Plan

children.title: Policy
children.content:
Momentum Is Building to Put Health Care Where Kids Are, in Schools!

Communities across California are fired up about the school-based health center movement  — and the momentum is undeniable. From cities to rural towns, people are coming together to advocate for school-based health centers (SBHC) and wellness centers (WC) and actively pursuing local, state, federal, and philanthropic support to start, enhance, and sustain these vital health services. Progress is happening — but we’re just getting started. Thousands more children, youth, and families still need access to the life-changing care that SBHCs/WCs provide. The California School-Based Health Alliance (CSHA) is leading the charge and shaping the policy landscape to expand comprehensive school health services across the state. Every year, we zero in on bold policy priorities and take strong stands on key legislation — all with one mission in mind: to ensure every student has the support, care, and resources they need to be healthy, safe, ready to learn and thrive. Goal 1: Advocate for state funding to start, improve, and expand new school-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHCs/WCs). Goal 2: Ensure students’ access to physical, mental, sexual + reproductive health by protecting access to medically accurate, confidential, culturally relevant, and age-appropriate health services in schools. Goal 3: Champion school environments that support whole child well-being so students can thrive. As part of its advocacy mission, the California School-Based Health Alliance (CSHA) often takes public positions on bills, ballot initiatives, and public policy issues that other organizations are sponsoring. Recognizing that improving the health and academic success of children and youth is impacted by many factors, systems, and policies and to further the mission of advancing health services in schools, CSHA supports legislation and policies that: Stay informed. Be inspired. Join the movement. Explore the latest updates on health and education policies that are transforming school health in California — and find out how you can help power the next wave of change.

children.title: Existing Laws
children.content:
California Laws Related to School-Based Health Centers

AJR 10 (Brownley): School-Based Health Centers (2011)

Resolution Chapter 68, Statutes of 2011; sponsored by the California School-Based Health Alliance This resolution was passed by the California Legislature in 2011. AJR 10 affirms the Legislature’s support for the federal school-based health center program authorized by Congress in 2010 and calls for an appropriation by Congress for that program. It also affirms the Legislature’s support for state and federal policies that include school-based health centers as partners for creating medical homes for all children, and for the inclusion of school-based health centers in the reauthorized Elementary and Secondary Education Act as an important strategy for ensuring that students are physically and mentally healthy and therefore ready to learn. Read the full text of AJR 10 (PDF).

SB 564 (Ridley-Thomas): The School Health Centers Expansion Act (2008)

Chapter 381, Statutes of 2008; sponsored by the California School-Based Health Alliance Signed by Gov. Schwarzenegger in September 2008, SB 564 builds upon an earlier Ridley-Thomas bill, AB 2560, which established a Public School Health Center Support Program. SB 564 created a grant program for school health centers administered by the Public School Health Center Support Program. To date, the grant program has not been funded. Read the full text of SB 564 (PDF).

AB 2560 (Ridley-Thomas): The School Health Centers Act (2006)

Chapter 334, Statutes of 2006; sponsored by the California School-Based Health Alliance Signed by Gov. Schwarzenegger on Sept. 19, 2006, this law created a Public School Health Center Program jointly administered by the Department of Health Services and the Department of Education. The program was designed to collect school health center data, facilitate the development of comprehensive health centers in partnership with California public schools, and address the programmatic, clinical, finance, and policy needs of California’s school health centers. To date, the program has not been implemented because neither state funding nor staff was made available for the program. Read the full text of AB 2560 (PDF).

SB 620 (Presley): Healthy Start Support Services for Children Act (1991)

Chapter 759, Statutes of 1991 This bill established Healthy Start, which provides planning and implementation grants for school-based student support services and their coordination. Healthy Start programs offer: academic and educational support; youth development and employment services; family support services; and medical and mental health care. Many of California’s SBHCs started as Healthy Start programs. Healthy Start funding peaked at $39 million in the 1990s. In 2007, the program was funded at $10 million. Since 2007, no new Healthy Start grants have been awarded.

Federal Laws Regarding School-Based Health Centers

Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (aka Health Care Reform) (2010)

Public Law 111-148, Title IV, Subtitle B, Sec 4101 This piece of legislation defines school-based health centers as providing comprehensive primary care services, including both physical and mental health services, at or near a school, in a clinic operated by a qualified sponsoring agency. It establishes and appropriates funds for a one-time grant program for school-based health center facilities, equipment, and related expenditures. It authorizes but does not appropriate funds for a school-based health center grant program for equipment, training, management and operations, and personnel. Read the full text of the section of the legislation defining SBHCs. Read the portion of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act focused on SBHCs .

Children’s Health Insurance Program Reauthorization Act/Social Security Act (2009)

Public Law 74-271, Sec 2110(c)(9) This piece of legislation defines school-based health centers as providing comprehensive primary care services at or near a school, in a clinic operated by a sponsoring agency. It defines sponsoring agency as a hospital, public health department, community health center, nonprofit health care agency, local educational agency, or a program administered by the Indian Health Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, or an Indian tribe or organization. Read the full text of the section of the legislation defining SBHCs .

children.title: Trainings & Technical Assistance
children.content:
The California School-Based Health Alliance offers a wide range of workshops, technical assistance, and training services to help your school-based health center or school district start or improve health services. Training & TA topics are listed below and categorized by theme. Workshops, technical assistance, and training can all be tailored to meet the needs of your site.

Are you a member of the California School-Based Health Alliance?

Organization members receive between 2 and 5 hours of free technical assistance depending on level of support.

Training Topics

School-Based Health Center & Wellness Center Start-Up, Financing, Legal Issues

Planning a school-based health center or wellness center but not sure how to get started? Looking for a partner health care provider or school? Forming a planning committee with new stakeholders? We can provide facilitated start-up planning committee meetings, as well as trainings on:

Operations & Practice

Want your SBHC to adopt best practices in clinical care, operations and school integration? We can provide trainings on:

Youth Leadership & Engagement

Looking to engage youth at your school-based health center or wellness center, or to develop your youth development skills? Planning to link your youth program to the statewide movement for school health? We can provide workshops to youth or trainings to adult facilitators on:

Mental Health in Schools & School-Based Health Centers/Wellness Centers

Interested in bringing mental health services on campus? Looking to improve school climate or conduct teacher trainings on mental health? We can assist you in planning and implementing comprehensive school mental health services for all students through:

children.title: Supporting School-Based Health Centers
children.content:
As the statewide nonprofit working to advance school-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHCs/WCs), our goal is to grow the number in California to 500 by 2030. In 2012, California had 200 SBHCs/WCs; today, there are 400 and counting . Across California , more than 408,000 students attend a school that has a health or wellness center, and many more have access to other types of school health services.

How Do We Define SBHCs/WCs?

A school-based health center (SBHC) is a student-focused health center or clinic located at or near a school that provides age-appropriate, medical services 2 by clinicians 3 . It may also provide behavioral health, dental, optometry, and/or ancillary services (i.e. health education, youth engagement, case management). A wellness center (WC) means a student-focused center 1 located at or near a school that provides age-appropriate, clinical behavioral health services 2 by providers 4 . It may also provide non-medical ancillary services. The American Academy of Pediatrics considers SBHCs to be an important way for students to get access to care and—because they are mostly located in communities with a high proportion of historically disadvantaged populations—an effective way to advance health equity. 1 The center may be a facility or a mobile unit, and must include at least one confidential treatment space appropriate to services provided, as well as an additional area for reception, enrollment, and triage 2 Services may be provided in-person or via telehealth 3 As defined by HRSA 4 As defined by California Board of Behavioral Sciences

A Growing Movement

As the statewide nonprofit working to advance school-based health centers, our goal is to grow the number of SBHCs/WCs in California to 500 by 2030. In 2012, California had 200 SBHCs/WCs; today, there are 400 and counting . Across California , more than 408,000 students attend a school that has a health or wellness center, and many more have access to other types of school health services . School-based health centers and wellness centers are an innovative way to help ensure that children and youth have access to health care and do well in school. California has 400 and counting. See Impact & Locations School-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHCs/WCs) are uniquely situated to bring health care professionals and educators together to address the multifaceted needs of children, youth and families. Some SBHCs/WCs serve only students, while others also serve family members or the broader community surrounding the school.

Effectively Delivering Health Care to Young People

SBHCs/WCs put health care where students already spend most of their time – at school. They offer: Research has shown, and teachers and educators intuitively know, that healthier children are better students because they are able to focus in class and are not distracted by hunger, pain, stress, or a chronic illness.

Take a Virtual Tour!

children.title: Profiles of SBHCs/WCs
children.content:
Children and youth at schools across California get increased access to quality health care with every new school-based health center and wellness center (SBHC/WC) that opens. SBHCs/WCs are usually located directly on a school campus and provide primary care like any health clinic. They are typically staffed by nurse practitioners, nurses, mental health providers, as well as part-time physicians and medical students. Services are provided at no or low cost. No one is refused service for inability to pay. SBHCs/WCs across California provide elementary, middle, and high school students with easy access to health care. Many SBHCs/WCs also offer dental care, mental health care, leadership programs, after-school programs, and even have gardens for growing fresh produce. Here you can see what is happening at California’s SBHCs/WCs. Don’t see your SBHC/WC? Tell us about your SBHC/WC here . If you would like to start an SBHC at your school you can navigate our website for tools and resources to help you get started. Swipe to see more

children.title: A Lifeline to Students During the Pandemic
children.content:
The impact of having a school-based health center (SBHC) that provides counseling services, health services, and a space for young folks to engage in wellness is one that I personally would have loved to experience as a young person. I have never been to a school that has developed such a culture of care, responsibility, and support for students that El Cerrito High has as a result of having its SBHC, The James Morehouse Project . I’ve seen school serve as a major lifeline for students who have no social support, who don’t have a trusted adult to share their experiences, to process trauma, and gather the resources and support that they need to make it through the school day, the year, and the rest of their lives. Photo credit: James Morehouse Project I met a number of students supported by the SBHC since they started high school who were unable to get the support offered through other venues that they received at the SBHC. These students have been able to transform themselves and ground themselves in their own values, their own truth, and their own terms in ways I have not seen at other schools. Even during the pandemic, I was able to maintain connections and support students as we experienced the collective trauma of quarantine and shelter in place and being removed from what often can be for many students one of the few safe spaces that they have in their day. Serving with just a phone call, an email, a text message, or video call was appreciated by the students I worked with who often had a hard time managing the different challenges that arose at home and that became more prevalent during the quarantine. Months into shelter in place and distance learning, we see that school-based health centers serve a vital role to continue to support students, families, and communities as we continue to face together the different challenges arising on a national level.

Programs During the Pandemic Included

Shared by Gilbert Gammad, MSW Candidate, UC Berkeley Counseling Intern at The James Morehouse Project SBHC, El Cerrito High School, Spring 2020

children.title: Community Schools
children.content:
Every Community School should have a school-based health center – José Muñoz, Director, Coalition for Community Schools A community school is a school that utilizes a “whole child” approach to education. They integrate a focus on academics with health, social services, community development and community engagement. A robust community school will include the following four pillars:

SBHC/WCs Are Aligned with Community Schools

California’s school-based health center & wellness center (SBHC/WC) model is a strong complementary asset to the goals and vision for community schools in the state. SBHC/WCs are a way for community schools to bring reliable, affordable, quality health and mental health care services to students and their families in an accessible and coordinated way.

SBHC/WCs & Community Schools Work Together

Our SBHC staff have developed a rare institutional trust with students, families, and community members, which is essential for providing care. The bottom line is that SBHCs provide essential health care in Oakland’s most high-need neighborhoods. – Curtiss Sarikey, Oakland Unified School District, from School-Based Health Centers: Trusted Lifelines in a Time of Crisis

State Funding: California Community Schools Partnership Program

The California Department of Education introduced a new investment for the planning, implementation, and support of community schools through the California Community Schools Partnership Program. RFAs for planning, implementation, and technical assistance grants have been released with coordination grants to be released soon. The first round of RFAs were due April 1, 2022, but the CDE plans to release another round for planning and implementation grants in the fall of 2022. The goal of this program is to improve student outcomes through supporting schools in partnering with community agencies and local governments. Funds through the Community Schools Partnership Program cannot be used for construction of School-based Health and Wellness Centers but can be used to purchase mobile health units to provide health, dental, vision and mental health services. LEAs can use this opportunity to launch new services using their own personnel, or partnering with community health providers.

Learn More About CCSPP

How LEAs & Partners Can Braid New Funding to Support SBHC/WCs

The California School-Based Health Alliance (CSHA) has a Braided Funding Guide to assist in local planning and strategy that shows local education agencies (LEAs) and partners how they can braid together new state funding opportunities – including those for full-service community schools – to support new school-based health centers (SBHC/WCs) or expand and improve existing SBHC/WCs.

See the Braided Funding Guide

Resources

The Coalition for Community Schools: The Coalition for Community Schools is a national organization advancing the community schools movement. Community Schools – A Full Spectrum Resource: This article was published in Leadership, the magazine of the Association of California School Administrators. It provides a useful overview of the community schools approach and its impact for students.

Who We Are / What We Do

children.title: Sample – 2025 School Health Conference
children.content:
The Power of Partnerships

Our 2025 School Health Conference will be held April 28-29, 2025, at the Hyatt Regency Orange County near Anaheim. Sign up for our newsletter to get the latest updates on registration and more.

Space Is Filling Up Fast. Register Today!

Our non-member rate is $600 (plus fees). Members of CSHA receive a discount of $200 – a tremendous value for two full days of learning and networking!

Scholarship Information

We are able to offer a limited number of scholarships with a reduced registration fee of $50 for individuals with financial need, and school health stakeholders in the Central Valley, the Inland Empire, and rural Northern California. We are confirming scholarships on a rolling basis.

Become a Member

If your organization is not yet a member it is not too late to sign up!
Being an organizational member of CSHA helps support the mission to create a more equitable future for children and youth in the Golden State. Organizations that want to receive individualized support for starting and expanding school health services, discounted conference registration, and access to knowledge and resources beyond what we have on our website are encouraged to become members.

Key Note Speakers

Clinical Director of Child, Adolescent and Young Adult programs at UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital Oakland Behavioral Health Department Morbi ut suscipit eros, non porttitor quam. Are you with a member organization? Check our member list . Is your organization not yet a member? See benefits and become a member today!

Monday, April 28

Tuesday, April 29

Who Attends?

What Topics Are Discussed?

Experience Our Mobile Unit Showcase

April 28, 11:00 am-4:30 pm: Join us for an exciting feature to this year’s School Health Conference: a comprehensive mobile health unit showcase! Explore both provider-operated units and a manufacturer model up close. Meet the dedicated teams bringing healthcare where kids are, at school.

Evening Reception at Bowlero

Attendees are invited to join us for a private reception at Bowlero Bowling Alley on Monday evening in the GardenWalk complex, just an 8-minute drive from the conference venue. We’ve reserved the entire space exclusively for conference attendees to enjoy an evening of networking, socializing, bowling, arcade games, and more. Complimentary appetizers, drinks, and activities are included at no cost! Don’t miss this exciting opportunity to unwind, have fun and connect with fellow attendees!

Take Advantage of Discounted Disneyland Tickets!

We’re thrilled to offer attendees discounted Disneyland tickets! These can be purchased through Disney’s online ticket store through Sunday, April 27, 2025. Tickets are valid from Thursday, April 24, through Monday, May 5, 2025. You can find the link to buy tickets in your registration confirmation email from Eventbrite. Our conference will be held at the Hyatt Regency Orange County – less than 20 miles from both John Wayne and Long Beach airports. There is limited room available at the Hyatt with our discounted room block rate.

Where will the conference be held?

The conference will take place at the Hyatt Regency Orange County , less than 2 miles from Disneyland, and less than 20 miles from both John Wayne and Long Beach airports.

Will you be offering continuing education (CE) credits for any workshops?

We hope to be offering CEUs for at least one of our workshops and will provide more details on the workshop and hours offered when information is confirmed.

Is there a discount for the hotel where the conference will be held?

Our room block at the Hyatt Regency Orange County is sold out. You can see alternative nearby hotels with availability in the above section of this page .

I have a promo code. How do I use it?

Click the “Tickets” button on the top right of this screen. A window will pop up with “General Admission” and the price per ticket. There is a small blue “Enter promo code” link above that. Click on the link, enter your promo code, and press apply.

I am presenting. How do I register?

You should receive instructions that will include a code that you can enter above the General Admission listing when you get to the registration form (after clicking on the “Tickets” button on the top right). There is a small blue “Enter promo code” link above that. Click on the link, enter your promo code and press apply. Presenters receive a discounted registration rate of $150.

Do you offer scholarships?

We are able to offer a very limited number of scholarships with a reduced registration fee of $50 for individuals with financial need. You can submit an application here . We plan to confirm scholarships starting in early March.

Will there be an evening reception during the conference?

After Monday’s workshops, join us for a private reception at Bowlero Bowling Alley from 5:30-8:00 pm in the GardenWalk complex, just an 8-minute drive from the conference venue. We’ve reserved the entire space exclusively for conference attendees to enjoy an evening of networking, socializing, bowling, arcade games, and more. Complimentary appetizers, drinks, and activities are included at no cost! Don’t miss this exciting opportunity to unwind, have fun and connect with fellow attendees!

Does the conference include a discount for Disneyland Parks?

We’re thrilled to offer attendees discounted Disneyland tickets! These can be purchased through Disney’s online ticket store through Sunday, April 27, 2025. Tickets are valid from Thursday, April 24, 2025 through Monday, May 5, 2025. You can find the link to buy tickets in your registration confirmation email from Eventbrite.

Are meals provided?

We provide breakfast and lunch on both days. Our evening reception at Bowlero includes heavy appetizers and a free drink coupon.

What times are the conference sessions?

The schedule will be posted on the CSHA conference web page . The conference takes place from 8:30 am – 5:00 pm Monday and 8:30 am – 3:30 pm on Tuesday with plenaries and concurrent morning and afternoon breakout sessions. You will choose workshop sessions in the morning and afternoon with a hosted lunch in between. We will offer breakfast and lunch.

Where do I park and how much is it?

Self-parking is available at $20 per day with the conference discount, while valet parking is $36 per pay with no discount. Be sure to get your parking ticket validated at the registration table to receive the discount.

Can the conference sell out?

We are expecting between 700 and 800 attendees. Our conference does sell out so register early to make sure you can attend.

Will any part of the conference be streamed or presented virtually?

We will not be streaming or virtually presenting any part of the conference this year.

Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?

No, you do not need to bring a printed ticket to this event.

Can I update my registration information?

Yes. Log in to your Eventbrite account to update your registration information.

What is your cancellation and refund policy?

Conference registration is on a first-come, first-served basis. Your registration is confirmed once payment is made via credit card at the time of registration. In the event that you need to cancel, your cancellation request will need to be submitted to CSHA via email on or before Monday, March 31, 2025 . You have the option to transfer your ticket to another person at any time. Please note that refunds are subject to a $75 cancellation fee per attendee. While tickets can still be transferred after March 31, 2025, no refunds will be issued for cancellation received after this date.

Do you accept purchase orders or checks as a form of payment for conference registration?

As of this year, the conference only accepts credit cards for registration payments. Purchase orders and checks are no longer accepted. Organizations without a dedicated credit card have found solutions by using a supervisor’s or colleague’s card, requesting a one-time limit increase, or spreading transactions over multiple days to stay within card limits. Alternatively, some organizations work with their purchasing departments to initiate a requisition and convert it into a credit card payment instead of completing a purchase order. If you need assistance, please email us .

Is my ticket transferrable?

Registration transfers are allowed and may be made by the registrant directly in our registration system at any time, without an additional fee, using the link provided in your confirmation email from Eventbrite or on the registration confirmation page. From there, you can update the ticket holder’s name and email address, if the option is available. If your ticket was purchased by someone else, the transfer option may not be accessible to you. In these cases or if you encounter any issues, please email CSHA for assistance.

Do you have a photo release or media policy?

Registration and attendance at, or participation in, California School-Based Health Alliance’s meetings and other activities constitutes an agreement by the registrant to the California School-Based Health Alliance’s use and distribution (both now and in the future) of the registrant or attendee’s image or voice in photographs, videotapes, electronic reproductions, and audiotapes of such events and activities.

What do you do with the information we provide during registration?

California School-Based Health Alliance reserves the right to update California School-Based Health Alliance’s database with information provided by registrants for the 2025 California School Health Conference.

I have a question not covered here, how do I get help?

For any questions not covered by the FAQ, please email CSHA at conference@schoolhealthcenters.org and we will get back to you as soon as possible.

Thank You to Our 2025 Sponsors!

Presenting Sponsor

CalOptima Health is the single largest health insurer in Orange County administering Medi-Cal for nearly 1 million Orange County residents. Our mission is to serve member health with excellence and dignity, respecting the value and needs of each person.

Platinum Sponsor

Blue Shield of California strives to create a healthcare system worthy of our family and friends that is sustainably affordable. Blue Shield of California is a tax paying, nonprofit, independent member of the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association with 8 million members, 7,200 employees and more than $24 billion in annual revenue. Founded in 1939 in San Francisco and now headquartered in Oakland, Blue Shield of California and its affiliates provide health, dental, vision, Medicaid and Medicare healthcare service plans in California. The company has contributed more than $643 million to Blue Shield of California Foundation since 2002 to have an impact on California communities.

Gold Sponsor

Anthem is dedicated to delivering better care to our members, providing greater value to our customers and helping improve the health of our communities.

Silver Sponsor

Schools are passionate about ensuring that all students succeed, but they can’t address the health of their employees and students alone. That’s why Kaiser Permanente created Thriving Schools . We’re committed to serving as a valuable partner in health to schools and districts across the country, helping to ensure that teachers, staff, and students have the support they need to thrive — in learning and in health.

Bronze Sponsor

Eager minds, healthy bodies, and quality care: The Los Angeles Trust for Children’s Health is bringing health and education together to end healthcare inequities and achieve student wellness for all.

Bronze Sponsor

ACEs Aware is a first-in-the nation effort to promote early detection and intervention to mitigate the health and societal impacts of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) and toxic stress. We offer free training, screening tools, clinical protocols, and payment for ACE screening. ACEs Aware strives to create a better world for our children, families, and communities by working together across sectors to prevent and address the impact of ACEs and toxic stress.

Stay Up to Date ON School-based Health

Stay informed & advocate for kids’ health. Get resources & access to our expert consultants.

webpage_tree.content:
Putting Health Care Where Kids Are

About CSHA

The California School-Based Health Alliance (CSHA) is the statewide non-profit organization dedicated to improving the health & academic success of children & youth by advancing health services in schools.

SUPPORTING SCHOOL BASED HEALTH CENTERS

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE &TRAININGS

POLICY & ADVOCACY IN CALIFORNIA

RESOURCES & GUIDANCE

Explore Our Resources

See our A-Z guide to starting a school-based health and wellness center! See how to protect patient data and confidentiality. Swipe to see more

About School-Based Health

School-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHCs/WCs) are an innovative way to help ensure that children and youth have access to health care and do well in school. A school-based health center (SBHC) is a student-focused health center or clinic located at or near a school that provides age-appropriate, medical services by clinicians. It may also provide behavioral health, dental, optometry, and/or ancillary services (i.e. health education, youth engagement, case management). A wellness center (WC) is a student-focused center located at or near a school that provides age-appropriate, clinical behavioral health services by providers. It may also provide non-medical ancillary services. Research has shown, and teachers and educators intuitively know, that healthier children are better students because they are able to focus in class and are not distracted by hunger, pain, stress, or a chronic illness.

Get the Latest Information on School Health

Sign up to receive our free newsletter and stay updated on learning opportunities and more. Organizations that want to receive technical assistance, discounted conference registration, and access to regular member calls can become a member.

Learning Opportunities

Asthma

School-Based Health Centers Help Manage Asthma School-based health centers (SBHCs) help children, youth, and families manage asthma, keeping kids out of the hospital and in school and saving money for our health care system. More specifically, recent research shows that: Resources for Practice The California School-Based Health Alliance has partnered with RAMP (a regional coalition…

Behavioral Health

Why School Behavioral Health Matters Schools are uniquely positioned to play an important, and potentially leading role in supporting the prevention and treatment of behavioral health challenges. Many students receive behavioral health services at their school: In fact, seventy percent of children receiving services get them at school, and the school environment is often a…

Case for School-based Peer-to-Peer Programs

The following is a list of resources that overview the rationale, models, planning and implementation of peer-to-peer mental health support.

Chronic Absence

School-Based Health Centers & Wellness Centers Can Help Schools Reduce Absence Because chronic absenteeism is the result of complex mental, physical, and family health issues, school-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHCs/WCs) can play an integral part in strategically addressing attendance problems. In collaboration with educators, health center staff can identify and support students with…

Organizations that want to receive individualized support for starting and expanding school health services, discounted conference registration, and access to knowledge and resources beyond what we have on our website are encouraged to become members. *Looking for more? webpage_tree.title: About
webpage_tree.content:
The California School-Based Health Alliance is the statewide nonprofit organization helping to put more health services in schools.

Our Mission

The California School-Based Health Alliance aims to improve the health and academic success of children and youth by advancing health services in schools.

Our Goals

Healthy Children. Too many children come to school every day suffering from conditions that seriously impact their ability to learn and succeed. Successful Students. Healthy students miss fewer classes, are less likely to drop out and have a better chance of success in school and beyond. Equity and Access. School-based health centers (SBHCs) offer services in a place that is familiar, trusted, age-appropriate, and convenient for all students and families – in school.

Our Work

Join Us

Sign up to receive our newsletter and occasional updates on student health in California. We are supported by private foundations, donations, and organizational and individual members . We are a state affiliate of the national School-Based Health Alliance in Washington, D.C. You can support our work for school-based health by becoming a member .

Support CSHA

We have earned a Platinum Seal with Candid (formerly GuideStar). We are a 501(c)(3) Public Charity.

SBIRT Quick Guide: Brief Interventions

Why Adopt Brief Interventions for Substance Use? Brief interventions are structured conversations designed to address alcohol and/or drug use among youth who are using substances, but do not need specialty SUD treatment. They are intended to be used when a young person screens positive for substance use or the need to discuss substance use emerges…

SBIRT Quick Guides

Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) is an evidence-based approach to the screening and identification of individuals engaged in substance use, the delivery of early brief interventions in order to reduce use, and the referral to treatment for high-risk use. The goal of these quick guides is to provide a brief overview of each…

Naloxone

The California School-Based Health Alliance (CSHA) recommends all school-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHC/WCs) have naloxone available and staff be trained to use it. What are naloxone and Narcan? Why should I have naloxone? Is naloxone safe? Is it safe for young people? Who is allowed to administer naloxone? Do I need parent/guardian consent…

Vaping & Mental Health

The Detrimental Intersection of Vaping & Youth Mental Health Over the past decade, there has been a notable surge in the number of young people turning to vaping products that contain nicotine, a trend exacerbated by the ongoing youth mental health crisis. Much of this rise can be attributed to the deceptive marketing tactics employed…

Tobacco/Cannabis

The Role of SBHCs in Tobacco Use Prevention & Education School-based health centers and wellness centers (SBHC/WCs) can help prevent tobacco use in students through health education and are well-positioned to provide tobacco cessation services.
